explanation:
To solve \((-6) \times \color{gold}\bigstar \color{black} = -8\), divide both sides by \(-6\):  
\(\color{gold}\bigstar \color{black} = \frac{-8}{-6} = \frac{8}{6}\).  

The student likely computed \(\frac{-6}{-8} = \frac{6}{8}\).  

This error stems from reversing the roles of dividend and divisor when isolating the variable. Instead of dividing \(-8\) by \(-6\), they divided \(-6\) by \(-8\).  

The misconception directly caused the inversion of the fraction’s numerator and denominator, as the student treated the coefficient \(-6\) (the divisor) as the dividend.  

This differs from "inverting the fraction when dividing," which involves reciprocals during fraction division, not misordering terms in a basic division step.
